subject: Aerospace Engineering
question_text: In a centrifugal compressor, the eye tip diameter is 10 cm. For a shaft rotational speed of 490 rotations per second, the tangential speed at the inducer tip is ___ m/s (rounded off to one decimal place).

tier_0_classification.classification_reasoning: This is a straightforward numerical calculation involving tangential speed. It requires applying the formula v = r*omega. The difficulty is low as it's a direct application of a formula.

answer_validation.reasoning: The tangential speed ($u$) at the inducer tip is calculated using the formula $u = \pi D N$, where $D$ is the eye tip diameter and $N$ is the rotational speed in rotations per second. Given the eye tip diameter $D = 10\text{ cm} = 0.1\text{ m}$ and the shaft rotational speed $N = 490\text{ rotations per second}$. Therefore, $u = \pi \times 0.1\text{ m} \times 490\text{ rps} = 49\pi \approx 153.938\text{ m/s}$. Rounded off to one decimal place, this is $153.9\text{ m/s}$.

step_by_step: Identify the given parameters and convert units: Eye tip diameter $D = 10$ cm $= 0.1$ m. Shaft rotational speed $N = 490$ rotations per second (rps).
Recall the formula for tangential speed (blade speed) at the tip of a rotating component: $u = \pi D N$, where $D$ is the diameter and $N$ is the rotational speed in rotations per second.
Substitute the given values into the formula: $u = \pi \times 0.1\text{ m} \times 490\text{ s}^{-1}$.
Calculate the tangential speed: $u = 49\pi \text{ m/s} \approx 153.938\text{ m/s}$.
Round the result to one decimal place as typically required for such problems: $u \approx 153.9\text{ m/s}$.

essential: Understanding of rotational speed in different units (rps vs rpm)
helpful: Familiarity with velocity triangles in turbomachinery

Main Concept: requires: Circumference formula for circular motion
requires: Relationship between linear speed and rotational speed
enables: Calculation of impeller tip speed for work input
enables: Analysis of centrifugal compressor performance

difficulty_factors: Direct application of a fundamental kinematic formula for tangential speed.

textbook_references.author: V Ganesan
textbook_references.text_snippet: The inducer is the entry section of the impeller blades. Its design significantly influences the overall compressor performance. The highest relative Mach number typically occurs at the tip of the inducer eye. If this Mach number is too high, shock waves can form, leading to significant efficiency losses. The inducer eye tip diameter (d_t1) is a critical design parameter.

textbook_references.author: V Ganesan
textbook_references.section: Worked Example: Effect of Prewhirl on Slip Factor
textbook_references.text_snippet: The impeller tip speed (u_2) is a critical design parameter.

video_references.topic_covered: Components of the Gas Turbine Engine, Fan Speed and Multi-Spool Design, Fan Tip Speed

step_by_step_solution.solution_path: Identify Given Data → Perform Unit Conversion (if necessary) → Apply Tangential Speed Formula → Calculate → Round off
key_insights: The eye tip diameter is the diameter at the inducer tip, where tangential speed is needed.
Rotational speed in rotations per second simplifies the formula to u = \pi D N without the 60 factor.

formulas_principles.name: Tangential Speed Formula
formulas_principles.conditions: When N is in rotations per second (rps)
formulas_principles.relevance: Core formula for calculating blade speed at a given diameter

formulas_principles.name: Tangential Speed Formula for rpm
formulas_principles.conditions: When N is in rotations per minute (rpm)
formulas_principles.relevance: Alternative form when speed is given in rpm

industry_examples: Centrifugal compressors in turbochargers for automotive engines
Small gas turbine engines for UAVs or auxiliary power units
High-speed rotating machinery in general, where peripheral speeds must be managed for structural integrity and aerodynamic efficiency.
real_world_applications.practical_relevance: Tangential speed at the inducer tip is a critical design parameter, affecting the relative Mach number and flow conditions. This is crucial for avoiding shock waves and ensuring efficient compressor operation. Exceeding critical tip speeds can also lead to material failure due to excessive centrifugal stress.

common_mistakes.mistake: Not converting diameter from centimeters to meters, leading to an answer that is off by a factor of 100.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: Carelessness or lack of attention to units.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Always write units next to numbers and convert to SI units (meters, seconds) before calculation.
common_mistakes.consequence: Answer would be 1.539 m/s instead of 153.9 m/s.

common_mistakes.mistake: Using the formula u = \pi D N / 60 even when N is given in rotations per second (rps), causing the answer to be too small by a factor of 60.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: Memorizing the formula for rpm without considering the units of N.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Check the units of rotational speed: if in rps, use u = \pi D N; if in rpm, use u = \pi D N / 60.
common_mistakes.consequence: Answer would be approximately 2.565 m/s instead of 153.9 m/s.

common_mistakes.mistake: Confusing the eye tip diameter with the mean eye diameter or impeller tip diameter, leading to incorrect diameter input.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: Lack of clarity on centrifugal compressor terminology.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Review centrifugal compressor components: inducer tip is the outermost point at the eye.
common_mistakes.consequence: If a different diameter is used, the tangential speed will be proportional to that diameter.

mnemonics_memory_aids.mnemonic: Pi D N for Speed: Remember that tangential speed (u) is \pi times Diameter times N (in rps).
mnemonics_memory_aids.context: When calculating blade speed in turbomachinery with rotational speed in rps.

flashcards.front: What is the formula for tangential speed (u) at a diameter D for rotational speed N in rotations per second?
How do you convert the formula if N is in rpm?
What common unit mistake must be avoided when calculating tangential speed?
flashcards.back: Always convert diameter to meters and ensure N is in correct units (rps or rpm) for the formula. Avoid using RPM directly without conversion.

flashcards.front: In a centrifugal compressor, what does the 'eye tip diameter' refer to?
flashcards.back: The diameter at the tip of the inducer at the compressor inlet, where air enters.

real_world_context.application: Design of centrifugal compressors for gas turbines
real_world_context.industry_example: In small turbojet engines, the inducer tip speed must be kept below supersonic to avoid shock losses.
real_world_context.why_it_matters: Excessive tip speed can lead to efficiency drops and mechanical stress.

exam_strategy.triage_tip: Quick calculation: use u = \pi D N with N in rps. Ensure diameter in meters. This is a straightforward formula application, attempt immediately.
exam_strategy.guessing_heuristic: If unsure, remember that for typical centrifugal compressors, tip speeds are in the range of 100-500 m/s. Try to reason through the problem logically if units or formula are unclear.
exam_strategy.time_management: Should take less than 1 minute to solve. Ensure units are consistent before calculation.

alternative_methods.name: First Principles Derivation
alternative_methods.description: Tangential speed is the linear speed at a point on a rotating body, derived from circumference times rotational frequency: u = (\pi D) * (N) for N in rps, since circumference is \pi D and frequency is N rotations per second.
alternative_methods.pros_cons: Pros: Fundamental understanding. Cons: Unnecessary for quick calculation.
alternative_methods.when_to_use: When learning the concept from scratch.

connections_to_other_subjects.Physics: Circular motion: linear velocity = radius * angular velocity (v = r\omega). Here, \omega = 2\pi N, so u = (D/2) * 2\pi N = \pi D N.
connections_to_other_subjects.Mechanical Engineering: Turbomachinery design principles apply similarly to pumps and turbines.
connections_to_other_subjects.Aerodynamics: In turbomachinery, the tangential speed of blade tips is critical for determining the relative Mach number, which dictates the onset of shock waves and aerodynamic losses.
connections_to_other_subjects.Fluid Mechanics: The tangential speed formula is derived from basic rotational kinematics principles.
connections_to_other_subjects.Mechanical Engineering (Machine Design): Understanding tangential speed is crucial for designing any rotating machinery, as it directly influences stress analysis (centrifugal forces) and dynamic performance.
connections_to_other_subjects.Physics (Rotational Kinematics): This problem is a direct application of fundamental principles of rotational motion, specifically the relationship between angular velocity and tangential velocity.
connections_to_other_subjects.Thermodynamics: The inlet conditions (temperature, pressure) affect the speed of sound and thus the inducer tip Mach number.

deeper_dive_topics: Effect of inducer tip speed on relative Mach number and compressor performance
Slip factor and its impact on work input in centrifugal compressors
Pre-whirl and inlet guide vanes to control inducer flow conditions
Centrifugal stress analysis in rotating components
Transonic flow phenomena at blade tips
